I would really appreciate advice on how to make use of threads when solving a large system of ODEs.
The function being solved can be thought of as:
 1) Assess all states and populate some matrices
 2) Act on columns of those matrices individually to calculate derivatives

The way I'm attempting to do this (which may well be terrible, please tell me if so) is to create one `ODEProblem` per thread in which the first step runs, then wait for all threads to finish step 1, then continues with the second step on a range of the columns of the matrices. This means that the second step can be threaded which gives a good speed improvement.

One of the difficulties is that I need to sync the ODEProblems themselves to make sure they're always solving the same timestep, and the syncing in general is a bit nasty/inefficient.

This feels like a hacky way of doing this, and I'd be grateful for any advice on either how to do this better or if this is an OK way how to sync simultaneous solving of ODE problems.

Thanks in advance.

Example code here:
```function f!(du, u, p t)
    # This function sets values used by all threads
    f_global!(du, u, p)

    # Need to sync all threads after f_global!
    sync_thread(Threads.threadid())

    # This function can be done on separate thread as per range and finish whenever
    f_separate!(du, u, p)
end

ranges = [1:10000, 10001:20000] # Assume two threads for this example
# u0, t_range, p exist

Threads.@threads for i in 1:Threads.nthreads()
    range = ranges[Threads.threadid()]
    prob = ODEProblem(f!, u0[range], t_range, p)
    sol = solve(prob, Tsit5())
    do_something_with_output(sol)
end```

Yeah its one big ODE. The first step in the function needs all of the states to populate some intermediate matrices and the second step just using the columns of that matrix. If I was doing it in one ODEProblem it would look like this:

```function f!(du, u, p t)
    f_global!(p, u, du) # modifies p

    for (i, col) in enumerate(eachcol(p.intermediate_matrices))
        du[i] = use_col(col, u[i])
    end
end```
And I'd like the for loop to be threaded. It seems that just using `Threads.@threads` isn't fast, I think due to context switching. It needed to be synced if split up into multiple ODEProblems that are solved independently, as for `use_col` to work for any index `f_global!` has to have finished

Hope that makes more sense
